abstract_summ: Seven of 27 patients (26%) had real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction confirmed-COVID-19 infection.RESULTS: The study included 236 patients (females 59/123, 25%; median age, 68 years).According to the COVID-19 S CT diagnosis criteria, the number of patients in the normal, compatible with COVID 19, indeterminate and alternative diagnosis groups were 581 (72.3%), 97 (12.1%), 16 (2.0%) and 109 (13.6%).A semi-quantitative CT score was calculated based on the extent of lobar involvement (0:0%; 1, < 5%; 2:5–25%; 3:26–50%; 4:51–75%; 5, > 75%; range 0–5; global score 0–25).MATERIALS AND METHODS Our study included 27 patients (mean age, 74 years; range, 54-90 years; 20 men) who underwent head CT for suspected stroke (n = 21) or head trauma (n = 6), additional chest CT for COVID-19 detection, and real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction testing in a COVID-19-endemic region.
title_summ: Assessment of a Diagnostic Strategy Based on Chest Computed Tomography in Patients Hospitalized for COVID-19 Pneumonia: an observational studyCorrelation between Chest Computed Tomography Scan Findings and Mortality of COVID-19 Cases; a Cross sectional StudyClinico-Radiological Evaluation and Correlation of CT Chest Images with Progress of Disease in COVID-19 Patients.SERIES FROM LOMBARDY REGIONThe role of initial chest X-ray in triaging patients with suspected COVID-19 during the pandemicThe performance of chest CT in evaluating the clinical severity of COVID-19 pneumonia: identifying critical cases based on CT characteristicsChest CT score in COVID-19 patients: correlation with disease severity and short-term prognosisChest X-ray features of SARS-CoV-2 in the emergency department: a multicenter experience from northern Italian hospitalsCOVID-19 pneumonia manifestations at the admission on chest ultrasound, radiographs, and CT: single-center study and comprehensive radiologic literature reviewWell-aerated Lung on Admitting Chest CT to Predict Adverse Outcome in COVID-19 PneumoniaDIAGNOSTIC IMPACT OF BEDSIDE CHEST X-RAY FEATURES OF 2019 NOVEL CORONAVIRUS IN THE ROUTINE ADMISSION AT THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT: CASE: Is it Worth to go the Extra Mile and Include the Chest to Screen for COVID-19 Infection?A Systematic Review of CT Chest in COVID-19 Diagnosis and its Potential Application in a Surgical Setting.An Imaging Tool for Assessing Severe COVID-19COVID-19 S: A new proposal for diagnosis and structured reporting of COVID-19 on computed tomography imaging.
title_abstract_phrases: Seven of 27 patients (26%) had real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction confirmed-COVID-19 infection.According to the COVID-19 S CT diagnosis criteria, the number of patients in the normal, compatible with COVID 19, indeterminate and alternative diagnosis groups were 581 (72.3%), 97 (12.1%), 16 (2.0%) and 109 (13.6%).RESULTS: The study included 236 patients (females 59/123, 25%; median age, 68 years).MATERIALS AND METHODS Our study included 27 patients (mean age, 74 years; range, 54-90 years; 20 men) who underwent head CT for suspected stroke (n = 21) or head trauma (n = 6), additional chest CT for COVID-19 detection, and real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction testing in a COVID-19-endemic region.A semi-quantitative CT score was calculated based on the extent of lobar involvement (0:0%; 1, < 5%; 2:5–25%; 3:26–50%; 4:51–75%; 5, > 75%; range 0–5; global score 0–25).
